page.title: List of Confederate monuments and memorials

revision.text:
{{see also|Removal of Confederate monuments and memorials|List of Union Civil War monuments and memorials|Modern display of the Confederate flag}} [[File:Confederate statue, Statesboro, GA, US.jpg|thumb|right|Statue in Statesboro, Georgia]]
This is a '''list of Confederate monuments and memorials''' that were established as public displays and symbols of the [[Confederate States of America]] (CSA), Confederate leaders, or Confederate soldiers of the [[American Civil War]]. Part of the [[commemoration of the American Civil War]], these symbols include monuments and statues, flags, [[Memorial Day#In the South|holidays]] and other observances, and the names of schools, roads, parks, bridges, counties, cities, lakes, dams, military bases, and other public works.<ref name="SPLC">{{Cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/20160421/whose-heritage-public-symbols-confederacy|title=Whose heritage? Public Symbols of the Confederacy|last=Gunter|first=Booth|last2=Kizzire|first2=Jamie|editor-last=Gunter|editor-first=Booth|website=Southern Poverty Law Center|date=April 21, 2016|access-date=October 6, 2017|quote=In an effort to assist the efforts of local communities to re-examine these symbols, the SPLC launched a study to catalog them. For the final tally [of 1,503], the researchers excluded nearly 2,600 markers, battlefields, museums, cemeteries and other places or symbols that are largely historical in nature.}}</ref>
[[Monument]]s and [[memorial]]s are listed below alphabetically by state, and by city within each state. States not listed have no known qualifying items for the list. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www-m.cnn.com/2018/06/05/us/confederate-monuments-texas-trnd/index.html|title=The state leading the way in removing Confederate monuments? Texas|publisher=}}</ref>
For monuments and memorials which have been removed, consult [[Removal of Confederate monuments and memorials]].
This list does not include the removal of figures connected with the [[origins of the Civil War]] or [[white supremacy]], but not with the Confederacy, including statues of Supreme Court Justice [[Roger B. Taney]] in Annapolis, Baltimore, and Frederick, Maryland, a controversial portrait of North Carolina Chief Justice [[Thomas Ruffin]],<ref>{{cite news |title=NC's highest court will review courtroom portraits amid complaint about pro-slavery judge |first=Josh |last=Shaffer |date=October 25, 2018 |newspaper=[[Island Packet]] |url=http://amp.islandpacket.com/news/state/north-carolina/article220617020.html}}</ref> and numerous memorials to Southern politician [[John C. Calhoun]] (commemorated on the Confederacy's 1¢ stamp). It also does not include post-Civil War [[white supremacist]]s, such as North Carolina Governor [[Charles Aycock]], some of whose monuments are also being removed (see [[Charles Brantley Aycock#Legacy]]). {{Horizontal TOC|nonum=y|limit=2}}
==History== ===Monument building and dedications=== [[File:Confedarate monuments (2).png|thumb|300px|Chart of public symbols of the Confederacy and its leaders as surveyed by the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] (SPLC), by year of establishment. Most of these were put up either during the [[Jim Crow]] era or during the [[Civil Rights Movement]], times of increased racial tension.<ref name="SPLC" /><ref name="NPR" /><ref name="CoxAnalysis" />{{refn|group=note|This chart is based on data from an SPLC survey which identified "1,503 publicly sponsored symbols honoring Confederate leaders, soldiers or the Confederate States of America in general." The survey excluded "nearly 2,600 markers, battlefields, museums, cemeteries and other places or symbols that SPLC deemed largely historical in nature"<ref name=":8" />}}]] Memorials have been erected on public spaces (including on courthouse grounds) either at public expense or funded by private organizations and donors. Numerous private memorials have also been erected.
According to [[Smithsonian Magazine]], "Confederate monuments aren't just heirlooms, the artifacts of a bygone era. Instead, American taxpayers are still heavily investing in these tributes today. We have found that, over the past ten years [2008–2018], taxpayers have directed at least $40 million to Confederate monuments—statues, homes, parks, museums, libraries and cemeteries—and to Confederate heritage organizations."<ref name=Smithson/>
====Early memorializations==== A small number of memorializations were made during the war, mainly as ship and place names. After the war, [[Robert E. Lee]] said on several occasions that he was opposed to any monuments, as they would, in his opinion, "keep open the sores of war".<ref>{{cite news |title=Actually, Robert E. Lee was against erecting Confederate memorials |date=August 16, 2017 |author=[[CNN]] |access-date=February 10, 2018 |newspaper=[[WPTV]] |url=https://www.wptv.com/news/national/actually-robert-e-lee-was-against-erecting-confederate-memorials}}</ref> Nevertheless, monuments and memorials continued to be dedicated shortly after the American Civil War.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://openlibrary.org/books/OL23304577M/History_of_Hampshire_County_West_Virginia|title=History of Hampshire County, West Virginia: from its earliest settlement to the present|last=Maxwell|first=Hu|date=1897|publisher=A.B. Boughner, printer|location=Morgantown, W. Va}}</ref>{{better source|date=August 2018}} Many more monuments were dedicated in the years after 1890, when [[United States Congress|Congress]] established the first [[National Military Park]] at [[Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park|Chickamauga and Chattanooga]], and by the turn of the twentieth century, five battlefields from the Civil War had been preserved: Chickamauga-Chattanooga, [[Antietam National Battlefield|Antietam]], [[Gettysburg National Military Park|Gettysburg]], [[Shiloh National Military Park|Shiloh]], and [[Vicksburg National Military Park|Vicksburg]]. At Vicksburg National Military Park, more than 95 percent of the park's monuments were erected in the first eighteen years after the park was established in 1899.<ref name=Vicksburg>{{cite web|title= Monuments and Memorials|url=https://www.nps.gov/vick/learn/historyculture/vnmp-state-memorials.htm|website=Vicksburg National Military Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=26 September 2017}}</ref>
====Jim Crow and white supremacy==== Confederate monument-building has often been part of widespread campaigns to promote and justify [[Jim Crow]] laws in the South, and assert [[white supremacy]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Leib|first=Jonathan I.|last2=Webster|first2=Gerald R.|last3=Webster|first3=Roberta H.|date=2000-12-01|title=Rebel with a cause? Iconography and public memory in the Southern United States|journal=GeoJournal|language=en|volume=52|issue=2|pages=303–310|doi=10.1023/A:1014358204037|issn=0343-2521}}</ref><ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/sites/default/files/whoseheritage_splc.pdf|title=Whose heritage? Public Symbols of the Confederacy|last=Gunter|first=Booth|last2=Kizzire|first2=Jamie|date=April 21, 2016|editor-last=Gunter|editor-first=Booth|website=Southern Poverty Law Center|format=PDF|access-date=August 15, 2017}}</ref><ref name="CoxAnalysis">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/posteverything/wp/2017/08/16/the-whole-point-of-confederate-monuments-is-to-celebrate-white-supremacy/|title=Analysis – The whole point of Confederate monuments is to celebrate white supremacy|last=Cox|first=Karen L.|date=16 August 2017|via=www.washingtonpost.com|accessdate=21 September 2017}}</ref> According to the [[American Historical Association]] (AHA), the erection of Confederate monuments during the early twentieth century was "part and parcel of the initiation of legally mandated segregation and widespread disenfranchisement across the South." According to the AHA, memorials to the Confederacy erected during this period "were intended, in part, to obscure the terrorism required to overthrow [[Reconstruction Era|Reconstruction]], and to intimidate African Americans politically and isolate them from the mainstream of public life." A later wave of monument building coincided with the civil rights movement, and according to the AHA "these symbols of white supremacy are still being invoked for similar purposes."<ref>American Historical Association, [https://www.historians.org/news-and-advocacy/statements-and-resolutions-of-support-and-protest/aha-statement-on-confederate-monuments AHA Statement on Confederate Monuments] (August 2017)</ref> According to [[Smithsonian Magazine]], "far from simply being markers of historic events and people, as proponents argue, these memorials were created and funded by Jim Crow governments to pay homage to a slave-owning society and to serve as blunt assertions of dominance over African-Americans."<ref name=Smithson>{{cite article |url=https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/costs-confederacy-special-report-180970731/#xqhmLkq8ks7k5PO9.99 |title=The Costs of the Confederacy |first1=Brian |last1=Palmer |first2=Seth Freed |last2=Wessler |magazine=[[Smithsonian Magazine]] |date=December 2018}}</ref>
According to historian Jane Dailey from the [[University of Chicago]], in many cases, the purpose of the monuments was not to celebrate the past but rather to promote a "white supremacist future".<ref name="NPR">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/08/20/544266880/confederate-statues-were-built-to-further-a-white-supremacist-future|title=Confederate Statues Were Built To Further A 'White Supremacist Future'|website=npr.org|accessdate=21 September 2017}}</ref> Another historian, Karen Cox, from the [[University of North Carolina at Charlotte]], has written that the monuments are "a legacy of the brutally racist Jim Crow era", and that "the whole point of Confederate monuments is to celebrate white supremacy".<ref name="CoxAnalysis" /> Another historian from UNC, James Leloudis, stated that "The funders and backers of these monuments are very explicit that they are requiring a political education and a legitimacy for the Jim Crow era and the right of white men to rule."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldsun.com/news/local/counties/durham-county/article167619947.html|title=Durham Confederate statue: tribute to dying veterans or political tool of Jim Crow South?|website=heraldsun.com|accessdate=21 September 2017}}</ref> They were erected without the consent or even input of Southern African-Americans, who remembered the Civil War far differently, and who had no interest in honoring those who fought to keep them enslaved.<ref name="SAHUpton">[http://www.sah.org/publications-and-research/sah-blog/sah-blog/2017/09/13/confederate-monuments-and-civic-values-in-the-wake-of-charlottesville Confederate Monuments and Civic Values in the Wake of Charlottesville]. [[Dell Upton]], [[Society of American Historians]], 13 September 2017</ref> According to Civil War historian Judith Giesberg, professor of history at [[Villanova University]], "White supremacy is really what these statues represent."<ref name="CSM">[https://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Politics/2017/0822/Confederate-monuments-What-to-do-with-them Confederate monuments: What to do with them?]. Grier, Peter. ''[[Christian Science Monitor]], 22 August 2017''</ref> Some monuments were also meant to beautify cities as part of the [[City Beautiful movement]], although this was secondary.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.csmonitor.com/Books/chapter-and-verse/2017/0614/Inside-the-hidden-history-of-confederate-memorials|title=Inside the hidden history of confederate memorials|last=Dotinga|first=Randy|date=2017-06-14|work=Christian Science Monitor|access-date=2017-09-05|issn=0882-7729}}</ref>
Many Confederate monuments were dedicated in the former Confederate states and [[Border states (American Civil War)|border states]] in the decades following the Civil War, in many instances by [[Ladies Memorial Association]]s, [[United Daughters of the Confederacy]] (UDC), [[United Confederate Veterans]] (UCV), [[Sons of Confederate Veterans]] (SCV), the Heritage Preservation Association, and other memorial organizations.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Winsboro|first=Irvin D.S.|date=2016|title=The Confederate Monument Movement as a Policy Dilemma for Resource Managers of Parks, Cultural Sites, and Protected Places: Florida as a Case Study|url=http://www.georgewright.org/332winsboro.pdf|journal=The George Wright Forum|volume=33|pages=217–29|via=}}</ref><ref name="Wiggins" /><ref name="ForsythPark" /> Other Confederate monuments are located on Civil War battlefields. Many Confederate monuments are listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]], either separately or as contributing objects within listings of courthouses or historic districts. Art historians Cynthia Mills and Pamela Simpson argued, in ''Monuments to the [[Lost Cause]]'', that the majority of Confederate monuments, of the type they define, were "commissioned by white women, in hope of preserving a positive vision of antebellum life."<ref>{{cite book|title=Monuments to the Los Cause: Women, Art, and the Landscapes of Southern Memory|last1=Mills|first1=Cynthia|last2=Simpson|first2=Pamela H.|publisher=University of Tennessee Press|year=2003|isbn=978-1572332720|page={{Page needed|date=October 2017}}}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gulley|first=H.E.|year=1993|title=Women and the Lost Cause: preserving a Confederate identity in the American Deep South|journal=Journal of Historical Geography|volume=19|issue=2|pages=125–41|doi=10.1006/jhge.1993.1009}}</ref>
In the late nineteenth century, technological innovations in the granite and bronze industries helped reduce costs and made monuments more affordable for small towns. Companies looking to capitalize on this opportunity often sold nearly identical copies of monuments to both the North and South.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/why-those-confederate-soldier-statues-look-a-lot-like-their-union-counterparts/2017/08/18/cefcc1bc-8394-11e7-ab27-1a21a8e006ab_story.html|title=Why those Confederate soldier statues look a lot like their Union counterparts|last=Fisher|first=Marc|date=2017-08-18|work=Washington Post|access-date=2017-09-16|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286|quote=Because of technological innovations in the granite and bronze industries, the price of these statues came way down}}</ref>
Another wave of monument construction coincided with the [[Civil Rights Movement]] and the [[American Civil War Centennial]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/20160421/whose-heritage-public-symbols-confederacy|title=Whose Heritage? Public Symbols of the Confederacy|last=|first=|date=April 21, 2016|publisher=Southern Poverty Law Center|access-date=September 15, 2017|quote=The second spike began in the early 1950s and lasted through the 1960s, as the civil rights movement led to a backlash among segregationists. These two periods also coincided with the 50th and 100th anniversaries of the Civil War}}</ref> At least thirty-two Confederate monuments were dedicated between 2000 and 2017, including at least 7 re-dedications.<ref name="GuardianChanging">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/aug/16/confederate-monuments-civil-war-history-trump|title='Changing history'? No – 32 Confederate monuments dedicated in past 17 years|last=Holpuch|first=Amanda|date=2017-08-16|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-08-26|last2=Chalabi|first2=Mona|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sovanow.com/index.php?/news/article/mecklenburg_confederate_statue_still_stands_after_anonymous_announces_threa/|title=Mecklenburg Confederate statue still stands after Anonymous announces threat {{!}} South Boston Virginia News {{!}} TheNewsRecord.com|website=www.sovanow.com|language=en|access-date=2018-08-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2017/05/30/confederate-statue-removed-from-university-louisville-campus-rededicated-in-kentucky.html|title=Confederate statue removed from University of Louisville campus rededicated in Kentucky|date=2017-05-30|work=Fox News|access-date=2018-08-22|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fpan.us/civilwar/monuments/ocala|title=FPAN - Destination: Civil War - - Ocala|website=fpan.us|access-date=2018-08-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.myajc.com/lifestyles/rededicating-confederate-monument-peace/FCAZ8OVP51wNkgycFVoS6K/|title=Rededicating a Confederate monument to peace|work=myajc|access-date=2018-08-22|language=en}}</ref>
[[File:Confederate Memorial in Fulton.jpg|thumb|right|upright|The [[Confederate Memorial in Fulton]], Kentucky is listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Fulton County, Kentucky|National Register of Historic Places]]]]
====Scholarly study==== Scholarly studies of the monuments began in the 1980s. In 1983 John J. Winberry published a study which was based on data from the work of R.W. Widener.<ref name="Widener">{{Cite book|title=Confederate monuments: Enduring symbols of the South and the War Between the States|last=Widener|first=Ralph W.|publisher=Andromeda Associates|year=1982|isbn=|location=|page=|oclc=8697924}}</ref><ref name=":2" /> He estimated that the main building period for monuments was from 1889 to 1929 and that of the monuments erected in courthouse squares over half were built between 1902 and 1912. He determined four main locations for monuments; battlefields, cemeteries, county courthouse grounds, and state capitol grounds. Over a third of the courthouse monuments were dedicated to the dead. The majority of the cemetery monuments in his study were built in the pre-1900 period, while most of the courthouse monuments were erected after 1900. Of the 666 monuments in his study 55% were of Confederate soldiers, while 28% were obelisks. Soldiers dominated courthouse grounds, while obelisks account for nearly half of cemetery monuments. The idea that the soldier statues always faced north was found to be untrue and that the soldiers usually faced the same direction as the courthouse. He noted that the monuments were "remarkably diverse" with "only a few instances of repetition of inscriptions".<ref name=":2" />
He categorized the monuments into four types. Type 1 was a Confederate soldier on a column with his weapon at parade rest, or weaponless and gazing into the distance. These accounted for approximately half the monuments studied. They are however the most popular among the courthouse monuments. Type 2 was a Confederate soldier on a column with rifle ready, or carrying a flag or bugle. Type 3 was an obelisk, often covered with drapery and bearing cannon balls or an urn. This type was 28% of the monuments studied, but 48% of the monuments in cemeteries and 18% of courthouse monuments. Type 4 was a miscellaneous group, including arches, standing stones, plaques, fountains, etc. These account for 17% of the monuments studied.<ref name=":2" />
Over a third of the courthouse monuments were specifically dedicated to the Confederate dead. The first courthouse monument was erected in Bolivar, Tennessee, in 1867. By 1880 nine courthouse monuments had been erected. Winberry noted two centers of courthouse monuments; the Potomac counties of Virginia, from which the tradition spread to North Carolina, and a larger area covering Georgia, South Carolina and northern Florida. The diffusion of courthouse monuments was aided by organizations such as the United Confederate Veterans and their publications, though other factors may also have been effective.<ref name=":2" />
Winberry listed four reasons for the shift from cemeteries to courthouses. First was the need to preserve the memory of the Confederate dead and also recognize the veterans who returned. Second was to celebrate the rebuilding of the south after the war. Third was the romanticizing of the [[Lost Cause of the Confederacy|Lost Cause]], and the fourth was to unify the white population in a common heritage against the interests of African American southerners. He concluded "No one of these four possible explanations for the Confederate monument is adequate or complete in itself. The monument is a symbol, but whether it was a memory of the past, a celebration of the present, or a portent of the future remains a difficult question to answer; monuments and symbols can be complicated and sometimes indecipherable."<ref name=":2">{{cite journal|title='Lest We Forget': The Confederate Monument and the Southern Townscape|authors=John J. Winberry|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/585508|year=2015|journal=Southeastern Geographer|volume=55|number=1|pages=19–31|subscription=yes|via=[[Project MUSE]]}}</ref>
===Removal=== {{Main|Removal of Confederate monuments and memorials}} [[File:Lee Removal.jpg|thumb|The Confederate Monument to Robert E. Lee is removed from its perch on May 17, 2017]] As of April 2017, at least 60 symbols of the Confederacy had been removed or renamed since 2015, according to the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] (SPLC).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2017/08/confederate-statues-debate-170821104705027.html|title=US Confederate monuments: What is the debate about?|website=www.aljazeera.com|accessdate=4 September 2017}}</ref> At the same time, laws in various states place restrictions on the removal of statutes and memorials and in some cases{{which|date=March 2018}} prohibit renaming of parks, roads, and schools.<ref name="vice.com">{{cite web|url=https://impact.vice.com/en_us/article/vbgpej/btw-these-four-states-legally-protect-confederate-monuments|title=BTW, These Four States Legally Protect Confederate Monuments|website=Impact|accessdate=4 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.djournal.com/news/state-news/mississippi-law-prohibits-removal-of-historical-markers/article_f4e8c3a6-82a2-54a7-bcf9-f8979d95322f.html|title=Mississippi law prohibits removal of historical markers|first=Bobby Harrison Daily Journal Jackson|last=Bureau|website=djournal.com|accessdate=4 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Cote|first1=Rachel Vorona|title=Heritage Act Keeps Confederate Flags Flying in South Carolina|url=https://jezebel.com/heritage-act-keeps-confederate-flags-flying-in-south-ca-1792769278|work=Jezebel|accessdate=2017-09-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.13wmaz.com/mb/news/local/georgia-state-law-makes-it-difficult-to-completely-remove-or-hide-confederate-monuments/464932603|title=Georgia state law makes it difficult to completely remove or hide Confederate monuments|website=13wmaz.com|accessdate=4 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/dc-politics/after-charlottesville-va-democrats-see-opening-to-change-114-year-old-monuments-law/2017/08/25/5e97e766-880e-11e7-a94f-3139abce39f5_story.html|title=After Charlottesville, Va. Democrats see opening to change 114-year-old monuments law|last=Olivo|first=Antonio|date=2017-08-25|work=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=2017-08-27|issn=0190-8286}}</ref><ref name="Reynolds">{{cite news |url=http://www.wmaz.com/mobile/article/mobile/article/news\local/georgia-state-law-makes-It-Difficult-to-Completely-Remove-or-Hide-Confederate-Monuments/93-464932603 |newspaper=WMAZ |date=August 17, 2017 |access-date=November 10, 2017 |title=Georgia State Law Makes It Difficult to Completely Remove or Hide Confederate Monuments |first=Jacob |last=Reynolds}}</ref>
A 2017 [[Reuters]] poll found that 54% of adults stated that the monuments should remain in all public spaces, and 27% said they should be removed, while 19% said they were unsure. The results were split along racial and political lines, with Republicans and whites preferring to keep the monuments in place, while Democrats and minorities preferring their removal.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-protests-poll/a-majority-of-americans-want-to-preserve-confederate-monuments-reuters-ipsos-poll-idUSKCN1B12EG|title=A majority of Americans want to preserve Confederate monuments: Reuters/Ipsos poll|date=21 August 2017|publisher=|accessdate=20 October 2017|via=Reuters}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ipsos.com/en-us/news-polls/reuters-ipsos-confederate-monuments-2017-08-22|title=Reuters/Ipsos Data: Confederate Monuments|website=ipsos.com|accessdate=20 October 2017}}</ref> A similar 2017 poll by HuffPost/YouGov found that one-third of respondents favored removal, while 49% were opposed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/confederate-statues-removal-polls_us_599de056e4b05710aa59841c|title=Polls Find Little Support For Confederate Statue Removal -- But How You Ask Matters|first=Ariel|last=Edwards-Levy|date=23 August 2017|publisher=|accessdate=20 October 2017|via=Huff Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://big.assets.huffingtonpost.com/tabsHPConfederateFlag20170815.pdf|title=HuffPost: Confederate Flag, August 15–16, 2017 – 1000 US Adults|website=huffingtonpost.com|accessdate=20 October 2017}}</ref>
==Geographic distribution==
Confederate monuments are widely distributed across the [[southern United States]].<ref name=":2" /> The distribution pattern follows the general political boundaries of the Confederacy.<ref name=":2" /> Of the more than 1503 public monuments and memorials to the Confederacy, more than 718 are monuments and statues. Nearly 300 monuments and statues are in Georgia, Virginia, or North Carolina. According to one researcher, "the absence of monuments in [[East Tennessee|eastern Tennessee]] and [[western North Carolina]] indicates those regions' Union sentiment, and the few monuments in Maryland, West Virginia, and Kentucky reflect those states' ambivalent war-time politics." The Northern States that remained part of the Union, as well as the Western States that were largely settled after the Civil War, have few or no memorials to the Confederacy.

===Arlington National Cemetery=== {{Main|List of memorials and monuments at Arlington National Cemetery}} [[File:Confederate Monument - S face tight - Arlington National Cemetery - 2011.jpg|thumb|upright|Confederate Memorial, Arlington National Cemetery]] * The antebellum home of Robert E. A [[National Park Service]] (NPS) memorial, the estate became the site of Arlington National Cemetery in part to ensure that Lee could never return to his home.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Beginnings of Arlington National Cemetery|url=https://www.nps.gov/arho/learn/historyculture/cemetery.htm|website=Arlington House, The Robert E. Lee Memorial|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=7 October 2017}}</ref>
:The NPS describes the property as "the nation's memorial to Robert E. Lee. It honors him for specific reasons, including his role in promoting peace and reunion after the Civil War. In a larger sense it exists as a place of study and contemplation of the meaning of some of the most difficult aspects of American History: military service; sacrifice; citizenship; duty; loyalty; slavery and freedom."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/arho/index.htm|title=Arlington House, The Robert E. ===Coins and stamps=== {{Also|Commemoration of the American Civil War on postage stamps}} * Robert E. Lee and Stonewall Jackson were portrayed by the [[US Mint]] on the [[Stone Mountain Memorial half dollar|1925 Commemorative silver US half dollar]], along with the words "Stone Mountain". The coin was a fundraiser for the [[Stone Mountain]] monument, which honors the Confederate Generals. The authorized issue was 5 million coins, to be sold at $1 each, but that proved overly optimistic and only 1.3 million coins were released, many of which ended up in circulation after being spent for face value.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.usrarecoininvestments.com/collecting/stone-mountain-halfdollar.htm|title=Information about the Stone Mountain Half Dollar coin|last=Pilitowski|first=Tom|date=|website=U.S. Rare Coin Investments|language=English|access-date=August 23, 2017}} </ref> The caption on the reverse reads "Memorial to the valor of the soldier of the South". * Robert E. Lee has been commemorated on at least five US postage stamps. * [[Coat of arms of Alabama|Alabama Coat of Arms]] (1923) and the State Seal include the Confederate Battle Flag. * [[Alabama State Flag]] (1895) The Alabama Department of Archives and History found in 1915 that the flag was meant to "preserve in permanent form some of the more distinctive features of the Confederate battle flag, particularly the St. Andrew's cross."<ref name="msnbc.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/these-5-states-still-use-confederate-symbols-their-flags|title=These 5 states still use Confederate symbols in their flags|website=Msnbc.com|accessdate=August 19, 2017}}</ref> According to historian John M. Coski, the adoption of Alabama's flag coincided with the rise of [[Jim Crow laws]] and [[Segregation in the United States|segregation]],<ref name=Coski8081>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zs0VJTbNwfAC&pg=PA80#v=onepage&q&f=falsee|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160309032406/https://books.google.com/books?id=zs0VJTbNwfAC&pg=PA80#v=onepage&q&f=falsee|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2016-03-09|title=The Confederate Battle Flag: America's Most Embattled Emblem|year=2005|first=John M.|last=Coski|accessdate=March 8, 2016|pages=80–81|location=United States of America|publisher=First Harvard University Press|isbn=978-0-674-01983-6|quote=The flag changes in Mississippi, Alabama, and Florida coincided with the passage of formal Jim Crow segregation laws throughout the South. Four years before Mississippi incorporated a Confederate battle flag into its state flag, its constitutional convention passed pioneering provisions to 'reform' politics by effectively disenfranchising most African Americans.}}</ref> as other former Confederate slave states, such as [[Mississippi]] and Florida, also adopted new state flags based off Confederate designs around the same time when [[Slave states and free states|those states]] instituted Jim Crow segregation laws themselves:<ref name=Coski8081/> * The [[Flag of Alabama#Governor's flag|Governor's version of the State Flag]] includes St Andrew's Cross plus the State Coat of Arms with the Confederate Battle Flag inclusion and the military crest on the bottom.

===City symbols=== * [[Panama City, Florida|Panama City]]: city flag is quite similar to the Florida state flag with a white background and the St Andrews cross echoing the Confederate Battle Flag, but with the city seal replacing the state seal.
==Georgia== {{also|Removal of Confederate monuments and memorials#Georgia}} There are at least 174 public spaces with Confederate monuments in Georgia.<ref name=":8" />
A law from the early twentieth century, last amended in 2004, says that no publicly-owned military monuments can be relocated, removed, concealed, obscured, or altered unless it is to preserve, protect, or help interpretation.<ref name="Reynolds"/>
===State capitol=== {{anchor|Georgia Capitol}} * CSA Gen. [[John Brown Gordon]] Memorial, [[Georgia State Capitol]] grounds. (1907, a year after the [[Atlanta Race Riot]]. "One of the leading proponents of both the [[New South]] creed and the [[Lost Cause]], a philosophy that greatly romanticized the South's role in the war. Moreover, he is generally acknowledged as having been the head of the [[Ku Klux Klan]] in Georgia. Gordon defended [[slavery in the United States|slavery]] as 'morally, socially and politically right' and called the Klan 'a brotherhood of peaceable, law-abiding citizens.'"<ref name=Capitol>{{cite news |title=Georgia Capitol heavy with Confederate symbols |first=Chris |last=Joyner |newspaper=[[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]] |date=September 5, 2015 |accessdate=May 25, 2018 |url=https://politics.myajc.com/news/state--regional-govt--politics/georgia-capitol-heavy-with-confederate-symbols/z051suEoa7bqO5cWhXlZnJ/}}</ref> * Statue of [[Benjamin Harvey Hill]], Confederate Senator, Georgia State Capitol.<ref name=Myajc /> * Statue of [[Joseph E. Brown|Joe Brown]] and his wife. "Brown was the Confederate governor of Georgia and after the war served as [U.S.] senator. He also was an ardent secessionist who played on white fears of interracial mingling. After the war, Brown served briefly as chief justice of the [[Supreme Court of Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia Supreme Court]] and authored an opinion upholding the state's ban on interracial marriage that described such marriages as 'productive of evil, and evil only, without any corresponding good.'... That opinion was cited in several briefs in the [[Obergefell v. Hodges|Supreme Court's recent decision on gay marriage]] as an example of how government has consistently erred in defining marriage."<ref name=Capitol /> * Painting of [[Hoke Smith]], Governor and U.S. Senator. "Smith was a fiery white supremacist who was evangelical in his opinions. In 1911... Smith told The New York Times that blacks were not capable of governing themselves and claimed a half-century of freedom had hurt black farmers. 'Under slavery they were compelled to work and forced to learn within the limits of their capacity,' he said. 'Now there is no compulsion, and many of them neither work nor learn.'" As governor in 1906 "successfully pushed through a [[literacy test]] for voters and constitutional amendment known as the '[[grandfather clause]]'".<ref name=Capitol /> * Plaque and tree honoring [[William Ambrose Wright]], a lieutenant in the [[Confederate States Army]], and Georgia state comptroller for fifty years, as well as insurance commissioner. ===Stone Mountain (state monument)=== [[File:Stone Mountain, the carving, and the Train.jpeg|thumb|[[Stone Mountain]] Confederate Memorial Carving (1923-72)]] Paid for and owned by the state of Georgia. When Georgia purchased the site, "it was designated as a memorial to the Confederacy".<ref>{{cite news |title=Birth of an idea: Where the King monument on Stone Mountain came from |first=Ernie |last=Suggs |newspaper=[[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]] |date=January 15, 2017 |url=https://www.myajc.com/news/local/birth-idea-where-the-king-monument-stone-mountain-came-from/HFpAfVTvdwvTXR4Td6UjHP/#}}</ref> The Stone Mountain Park officially opened on April 14, 1965 – 100 years to the day after [[Assassination of Abraham Lincoln|Lincoln's assassination]].<ref name=McKinney>{{cite magazine |title=Stone Mountain. A Monumental Dilemma |first=Debra |last=McKinney |pages=18–22 |magazine=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]] Intelligence Report |date=Spring 2018 |issue=164}}</ref> Site of the rebirth of the [[Ku Klux Klan#Second Klan: 1915–1944|Ku Klux Klan]] (the Second Clan), on the top of the mountain, with [[cross burning]], in 1915. ==Hawaii== * A plaque in the [[National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific]] commemorates Hawaiians who fought for the Confederacy, as well as Hawaiians who fought for the Union.
==Idaho== There are several places named for the Confederacy in [[Idaho]].<ref name=":8" /> The settlement of Idaho coincided with the Civil War and settlers from Southern states memorialized the Confederacy with the names of several towns and natural features.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=1983|title=History of the Boise National Forest, 1905–1976|url=https://www.fs.usda.gov/Internet/FSE_DOCUMENTS/fsbdev3_042206.pdf|journal=|publisher=Idaho State Historical Society|volume=|page=25|via=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ktvb.com/mb/amp/news/local/legacy-of-the-civil-war-in-idaho/464654495|title=Legacy of the Civil War in Idaho|last=Parsons|first=Gretchen|date=2017-08-16|website=www.ktvb.com|accessdate=2017-08-21}}</ref><ref name="confidaho">{{cite web|url=https://www.theclio.com/web/entry?id=21447|title=Lower Boise Historical Marker-Confederates in Idaho|website=Clio|access-date=August 24, 2017}}</ref>
===Inhabited places=== * [[Atlanta, Idaho|Atlanta]]: unincorporated, and its [[Atlanta Airport (Idaho)|Atlanta Airport]]. The area was named by Southerners after reports of a Confederate victory over Gen. Sherman in the [[Battle of Atlanta]], which turned to be wholly false, but the name stuck. * Confederate Gulch: unincorporated former mining community<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://idfg.idaho.gov/ifwis/fishingplanner/water/?id=3170|title=Confederate Gulch {{!}} Idaho Fishing Planner|last=Game|first=Brent Thomas, Idaho Fish and|website=idfg.idaho.gov|language=EN|access-date=August 21, 2017}}</ref><ref name="confidaho" /> * Grayback Gulch: unincorporated former mining community, settled by Confederate soldiers and named for the color of their uniforms. Now a government campground<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fs.usda.gov/recarea/boise/recarea/?recid=81261|title=Boise National Forest – Grayback Campground and Group|website=www.fs.usda.gov|accessdate=August 21, 2017}}</ref> * [[Leesburg, Idaho|Leesburg]]: an unincorporated former goldmining town settled by southerners and named for Robert E. Lee.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ktvb.com/amp//news/local/legacy-of-the-civil-war-in-idaho/464654495|title=Legacy of the Civil War in Idaho|last=Parsons|first=Gretchen|date=August 15, 2017|website=KTVB-TV|language=en|access-date=August 21, 2017}}</ref>

==Illinois== [[File:Confederate Mound cropped.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Confederate Monument at [[Oak Woods Cemetery]] in [[Chicago]]]] The only memorials in Illinois are in cemeteries and connected with prisoners of war. ===Federal cemeteries=== * [[Alton, Illinois|Alton]]: UDC monument (1909), North Alton Confederate Cemetery. Dedicated to Confederate soldiers who died at [[Alton Military Prison]]<ref>{{cite web | title = North Alton Confederate Cemetery | publisher = U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs | url = https://www.cem.va.gov/cems/lots/north_alton.asp | accessdate = October 12, 2017}}</ref> As of October, 2018, it is one of 7 cemeteries with Confederate monuments that the [[Veterans Administration]] has under 24-hour guard.<ref name=Veterans/> * [[Rock Island, Illinois|Rock Island]]: UDC obelisk (2003), Rock Island Confederate Cemetery. Dedicated to Confederate soldiers who died at [[Rock Island Military Prison]]<ref>{{cite web | title = Rock Island Confederate Cemetery | publisher = National Park Service | url = https://www.nps.gov/nr/travel/national_cemeteries/illinois/rock_island_confederate_cemetery.html | accessdate = October 14, 2017}}</ref> * [[Springfield, Illinois|Springfield]]: UDC/SCV monument (2005), [[Camp Butler National Cemetery]]. [[Mass grave]] and monument dedicated to Confederate soldiers who died at [[Camp Douglas (Chicago)|Camp Douglas]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Confederate Mound at Oak Woods Cemetery Chicago, Illinois | publisher = National Park Service | url = https://www.nps.gov/nr/travel/national_cemeteries/illinois/confederate_mound_oak_woods_cemetery.html | accessdate = October 12, 2017}}</ref> As of October, 2018, the [[Veterans Administration]] has it under dawn to dusk guard.<ref name=Veterans/> It is No. 7 on the [[Make It Right Project]]'s 2018 list of the 10 Confederate monuments it most wants removed.<ref>{{cite web |title=Announcing the Launch of the Make It Right Project |first=Kali |last=Holloway |date=June 3, 2018 |accessdate=September 10, 2018 |url=https://independentmediainstitute.org/make-it-right-project-announcement/ |publisher=Independent Media Institute}}</ref>

==Kansas== {{Also|Removal of Confederate monuments and memorials#Kansas}} There is one public space dedicated to the Confederacy in Kansas.<ref name=":8" /> * [[Humboldt, Kansas|Humboldt]]: Confederate Soldier Shot Historical Marker. The marker sits at the site of where the Union Flag was flying in Humboldt, Kansas, when a Confederate Soldier attempted to chop down the Union flag pole. The Confederate Soldier was shot as he tried to remove the flag. The marker is less of a monument to the Confederacy, and more of a historical marker describing the events when Humboldt was raided by Confederate Captains John Mathews and his friend Tom Livingston; they led other white Confederate proslavers, [[Native Americans in the American Civil War#Native Americans in the Confederate Army|Southern-sympathizing Indians]], and Missouri [[bushwhackers]] seeking fugitive slaves from Missouri who were hiding in Humboldt.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.humboldtkansas.org/civil_war_history.html|title=City of Humboldt, Kansas – Civil War History|website=Humboldtkansas.org|access-date=August 17, 2017}}</ref>

==Louisiana== {{Also|Removal of Confederate monuments and memorials#Louisiana}}
There are at least 91 public spaces with Confederate monuments in Louisiana.<ref name=":8" />
===State capitol=== * Gov. [[Francis T. Nicholls]] Statue (1934). Nicholls was a [[Brigadier General]] in the Confederate Army. * Gov. [[Henry Watkins Allen]] Statue (1934). Allen was a [[Brigadier General]] in the Confederate Army. He is buried on the [[Old Louisiana State Capitol]] grounds. * "Silent Sentinel" Monument, officially the Confederate Soldiers of East and West Baton Rouge Parishes Memorial. [[Plinth]] erected 1886 and statue in 1890. Dedicated by Gov. [[John McEnery]]. Original granite and marble plinth cracked; replaced in the 1960s with a small brick plinth that was aesthetically unappealing. Formerly at North Boulevard and 3rd Street, near City Hall. In 2012, to make room for Town Square construction, it was moved to the nearby [[Old Louisiana State Capitol]], now a museum.<ref name=225magazine>{{cite article |title=Will Confederate Landmarks in Baton Rouge Become the Subject of Controversy? |first=David |last=Jacobs |date=October 3, 2017 |magazine=225 Magazine |url=https://www.225batonrouge.com/our-city/will-confederate-landmarks-baton-rouge-become-subject-controversy}}</ref> Plaque reads: "Erected by the men and women of East and West Baton Rouge to perpetuate the heroism and patriotic devotion of the noble soldiers from the two parishes who wore the gray and crossed the river with their immortal leaders to rest under the shade of the trees. Original monument erected 1886 A.D."

===State symbols=== * [[Flag of Maryland]] (1904). The state flag of Maryland features the red-and-white Crossland Banner, the unofficial state flag of Maryland used by secessionists and Confederates during the American Civil War.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonian.com/2015/08/19/marylands-flag-confederate-symbol-crossland-banner-calvert-family/|title=Maryland's Flag Has a Subtle Symbol of Confederate Sympathy|last=Beaujon|first=Andrew|date=2015-08-19|website=Washingtonian|access-date=2017-08-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ggwash.org/view/38356/marylands-flag-may-be-more-symbolic-than-you-realize|title=Maryland's flag may be more symbolic than you realize|last=Johnson|first=Matt|date=2015-06-05|work=Greater Greater Washington|access-date=2017-08-29|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/features/baltimore-insider-blog/bs-fe-maryland-flag-confederate-20170803-story.html|title=Activist draws attention to Maryland flag's Confederate ties during #NoConfederate campaign|last=Tkacik|first=Christina|date=2017-08-03|work=[[The Baltimore Sun]]|access-date=2017-08-29|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://baltimore.cbslocal.com/2017/08/02/maryland-flag-confederate-history/|title=Does Maryland's Flag Have Confederate Ties? Social Media Campaign Sparks Controversy|last=|first=|date=2017-08-02|website=CBS Baltimore|access-date=2017-08-29}}</ref> The current state flag started appearing after the Civil War as a form of reconciliation. The flag became official in 1904. {{Begin flag gallery}}{{Flag entry|Width=200|Image=Flag of Maryland.svg|Caption=Flag of Maryland since 1904}}{{End flag gallery}} * The state song "[[Maryland, My Maryland]]" calls on the state to join the [[Confederate States of America|Confederacy]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/25/us/monuments-confederacy-remove-rename.html|title=Far From Dixie, Outcry Grows Over a Wider Array of Monuments|last=Gabriel|first=Trip|date=August 25, 2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en}}</ref> As of 2018, the [[Maryland General Assembly]] has eight times taken up the question of the state song, without enacting any change. In 2017, the [[Mighty Sound of Maryland]], the marching band of the [[University of Maryland at College Park]], stopped playing the song.<ref>Associated Press. [https://www.afro.com/umd-band-stops-playing-pro-confederate-song/ "UMD Band Stops Playing pro-Confederate Song"], ''[[Baltimore Afro-American|Afro]]'', Baltimore, 30 August 2017. Retrieved on 04 September 2017.</ref>

==Massachusetts== There are no public spaces dedicated to the Confederacy in [[Massachusetts]].<ref name=":8" />
===Private memorials=== * [[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]] ** Memorial Hall, [[Harvard University]]. Stained-glass windows to commemorate various figures, among them: *** Honor and Peace Window (1900). There is no inscription, but a Harvard University page ([http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~memhall/staingls.html]) explaining the windows says: "This window commemorates those who surrendered their lives in the War of the Rebellion." Portrays two warriors, one with sword high in triumph, one kneeling in defeat, who from the ribbons can be seen to be from different but related countries. *** Student and Soldier Window (1889). Soldier wears gray uniform.
==Mississippi== {{also|Removal of Confederate monuments and memorials#Mississippi}}
There are at least 131 public spaces with Confederate monuments in [[Mississippi]].<ref name=":8" />
===State capitol=== * [[Confederate Monument (Jackson, Mississippi)|Confederate Monument]], Mississippi Department of Archives and History Building, dedicated June 1891.<ref>Appleton's Annual Cyclopedia (1891), pp. 532–33</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.waymarking.com/waymarks/WMWD6K_Mississippi_Confederate_Monument_Jackson_MS|title=Mississippi Confederate Monument – Jackson MS|website=Waymarking|access-date=August 25, 2017}}</ref><ref name="auto6"/> In front of the [[Old Mississippi State Capitol|Old Capitol Museum]]. Unusual in that a former slave and [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] member of the legislature, [[John F. Harris (politician)|John F. Harris]], spoke passionately in favor of it, while some whites spoke against it. "Every colored member voted 'Aye'."<ref name="auto6">{{cite news |newspaper=[[Clarion Ledger]] |date=February 23, 1890 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14008221/the_monument_clarionledger_jackson/ |title=Monument}}</ref> * Women of the Confederacy Monument (1917), on south side of Capitol grounds. Cost was $20,000, sculpted by [[Belle Kinney Scholz|Belle Marshall Kinney]]. "The monument features two female figures and one male figure, a wounded and dying soldier. To the left of the soldier, a sympathetic woman is presenting a palm of glory to the soldier, a symbol of triumph even in death. Above both the soldier and the woman stands 'Fame'. She, in turn, is placing a wreath on the head of the woman in recognition of her contribution to the Confederate cause. Below the bronze figures are four inscriptions facing each direction, and dedicated to 'our' mothers, daughters, sisters and wives. On the southern face, which is the front of the monument, is a quote from Jefferson Davis which, among other virtues, praises the women 'whose pious ministrations to our wounded soldiers soothed the last hours of those who died far from the objects of their tenderest love.'"<ref>{{cite web |title=Mississippi's Women of the Confederacy Monument |date=October 24, 2012 |first=Jim |last=Woodrick |accessdate=June 12, 2018 |url=http://andspeakingofwhich.blogspot.com/2012/10/mississippis-women-of-confederacy.html}}</ref>

==North Carolina== {{further|North Carolina in the American Civil War}} {{Also|Removal of Confederate monuments and memorials#North Carolina}} There are at least 140 public spaces with Confederate monuments in North Carolina.<ref name=":8" />
Governor [[Roy Cooper]] "has called for the removal of monuments honoring Confederate soldiers and generals", including the Chapel Hill ''[[Silent Sam]]'' statue. He has called for the repeal of a 2015 law requiring legislative approval to remove Confederate monuments.<ref>{{cite news |title=Gov. Cooper gives UNC green light to remove ‘Silent Sam’, UNC holds off, citing 2015 law |date=August 22, 2017 |first=Jeff |last=Moore |url=https://nsjonline.com/article/2017/08/gov-cooper-gives-unc-green-light-to-remove-silent-sam-unc-holds-off-citing-2015-law/ |newspaper=[[North State Journal]]}}</ref>
===State capitol=== [[File:Raleigh,_NC_Confederete_Monument.JPG|thumb|State Confederate Monument to the west of the state capitol]] * [[North Carolina State Capitol]]. The Capitol currently houses the offices of the [[Governor of North Carolina]]. The legislature relocated to its current location in the [[North Carolina State Legislative Building]] in 1963.<br/>In 2017, Governor [[Roy Cooper]] unsuccessfully petitioned the North Carolina Historical Commission to move the following three Confederate monuments from the grounds of the state Capitol to the [[Bentonville Battlefield]], a [[American Civil War|Civil War]] site in [[Johnston County, North Carolina|Johnston County]].<ref>{{cite news |title=NC governor has a new site in mind for 3 Confederate monuments on Capitol grounds |first=Lynn |last=Bonner |newspaper=[[News & Observer]] |date=September 8, 2017 |url=https://www.newsobserver.com/news/politics-government/state-politics/article172115977.html}}</ref><ref name=Salisbury /> The Commission found that the 2015 law prohibited their removal, but recommended signage to add context to the monuments, including noting that slavery was a cause of the Civil War. The Commission also found unanimously that the Capitol monuments are "an overrepresentation and over-memorialization" of the Confederacy and Civil War in Georgia. The Commission urged the state’s Department of Natural and Cultural Resources to plan and raise money for a monument recognizing the contributions of African Americans to Georgia's history.<ref>{{cite news |title=Commission Votes Against Removing 3 Confederate Monuments in NC Capitol |first=David |last=Boraks |date=August 22, 2018 |newspaper=[[WFAE]] |url=http://www.wfae.org/post/commission-votes-against-removing-3-confederate-monuments-nc-capitol#stream/0 |accessdate=November 18, 2018}}</ref> ** North Carolina State Confederate Monument (1895), also known as the Soldiers and Sailors Monument. "This 75-foot-tall monument to fallen Confederate soldiers is located on the State Capitol grounds. At the top of the column is a statue depicting a Confederate artillery soldier holding a gun. Near the bottom of the column are two statues, one representing the Confederate infantry and the other a Confederate cavalryman. Two 32 pounder naval cannons stand on each side of the monument."<ref>{{cite web|title=Confederate Monument, State Capitol, Raleigh |publisher=Documenting the American South |url=http://docsouth.unc.edu/commland/monument/106/ |accessdate=April 15, 2018}}</ref> Contains the [[Seal of North Carolina]]. Front: "To Our Confederate Dead." Rear: "First at Bethel, last at Appomattox". ** Monument to North Carolina Women of the Confederacy, also called Confederate Women's Monument (1914). "The seven foot tall monument, made possible through a private donation, honors the hardships and sacrifices of North Carolina women during the Civil War. A bronze sculpture depicts an older woman, a grandmotherly figure, holding a book as she sits next to a young boy holding a sword. It sits on top of a granite base with bronze bas-relief plaques. The woman, representing the women in the South as the custodians of history, imparts the history of the Civil War to the boy. The two relief plaques portray the Civil War; the eastern side shows soldiers departing for war and leaving their loved ones behind, while the western side depicts a weary or injured Confederate soldier returning home."<ref>{{cite web|title=Monument to North Carolina Women of the Confederacy, Raleigh|publisher=Documenting the American South|url=http://docsouth.unc.edu/commland/monument/99/|accessdate=April 15, 2018}}</ref> ** Henry Lawson Wyatt Monument (1912). ==South Carolina== {{Also|Removal of Confederate monuments and memorials#South Carolina}} {{further|South Carolina in the American Civil War}} There are at least 112 public spaces with Confederate monuments in South Carolina.<ref name=":8" />
The state restricted the removal of memorials and statues with the South Carolina Heritage Act (2000), which states that "no historical monument can be altered or moved without a two-thirds vote in both chambers of the state's General Assembly".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.floridatoday.com/story/news/local/2017/08/14/s-c-law-protects-confederate-monuments/566472001/|title=Gov. McMaster doubts efforts to remove Confederate monuments will spread to South Carolina|last=Brown|first=Kirk|date=2017-08-14|work=Florida Today|access-date=2017-09-02|last2=Cary|first2=Nathaniel|language=en|last3=Mayo|first3=Nikie}}</ref>
===South Carolina State House=== : In August 2017, "a coalition of Columbia-area groups is calling for the S.C. Legislature to remove several monuments on the [[South Carolina State House|State House]] grounds."<ref>{{cite news |title=Protesters want Confederate monuments removed from SC State House |first=Bristow |last=Marchant |date=August 25, 2017 |access-date=April 15, 2018 |newspaper=''[[The State (newspaper)|The State]]'' |url=http://www.thestate.com/news/politics-government/article169295587.html}}</ref> * South Carolina's Confederate Dead (1879), also known as the South Carolina Soldiers Monument.<ref name="Brown">Thomas J. Brown, "The Confederate Retreat to Mars and Venus" in ''Battle Scars: Gender and Sexuality in the American Civil War'' (eds. Catherine Clinton & Nina Silber: Oxford University Press, 2006), p. 189-91.</ref> It was unveiled before a crowd of 15,000.<ref name="Prince">K. Michael Prince, ''Rally 'round the Flag, Boys!: South Carolina and the Confederate Flag'' (University of South Carolina Press, 2004), pp. 23-24.</ref> The monument was largely destroyed by lightning in 1882, but was replaced by the state two years later.<ref name="Prince"/> It is positioned on the northern end of the State House grounds. After a decision by the Legislature to remove the Confederate flag from the dome of the State House, where it had flown since 1962, the monument flew a traditional version of the [[Confederate Battle Flag]] from 2000 to 2015; the flag was the subject of protests and national level political debate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mobile.abc.net.au/news/2015-06-21/protesters-target-confederate-flag-after-charleston-killings/6561692|title=Charleston shooting: Thousands gather to protest Confederate flag after killings; Romney, Obama tweet support|website=mobile.abc.net.au|accessdate=August 21, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/national-international/Mitt-Romney-Twitter-Confederate-Flag-South-Carolina-Church-Shooting-308689091.html|title=Republican Candidates Weigh In on Confederate Flag Removal|website=nbcnewyork.com|accessdate=August 21, 2017}}</ref> In 2015 it was removed by a 2/3 vote of both houses of the Legislature.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/jul/10/confederate-flag-south-carolina-statehouse|title=Confederate flag removed from South Carolina capitol in victory for activists|last=Holpuch|first=Amanda|date=2015-07-10|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-08-26|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> It is displayed in the [[South Carolina Confederate Relic Room & Military Museum]]. * Monument to the South Carolina Women of the Confederacy (1912),<ref name=":8" /> a bronze monument by [[Frederic W. Ruckstull]].<ref name=Brown/> * [[Wade Hampton III]] Confederate Monument (1906),<ref name=":8" /> 16-foot bronze equestrian statue, also by Frederick Ruckstull. There is also a statue of him within the Capitol.<ref name=Schools>{{cite news |title=Yes, Schools In The U.S. Still Bear The Names Of White Supremacists |date=January 15, 2014 |newspaper=[[Huffington Post]] |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/01/15/white-supremacist-schools_n_4509352.html?slideshow=true |first=Rebecca |last=Klein}}</ref>

==Tennessee== {{Also|Removal of Confederate monuments and memorials#Tennessee|Nathan Bedford Forrest#Legacy}} {{further|Tennessee in the American Civil War}} There are at least 80 public spaces with Confederate monuments in [[Tennessee]].<ref name=":8" /> The [[Tennessee Heritage Protection Act]] (2016) and a 2013 law restrict the removal of statues and memorials.<ref name="vice.com"/>
The [[Tennessee legislature]] designated [[Confederate Decoration Day]], the origin of [[Memorial Day]], as June 3, and in 1969<ref>{{citation |last=Staples |first=Brent |date=9 Jan 2018 |title=Monuments to White Supremacy |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/09/opinion/monuments-white-supremacy-tennessee.html |publisher=New York Times}}</ref> designated January 19 and July 13, their birthdays, as Robert E. Lee Day and [[Nathan Bedford Forrest]] day respectively.
===Buildings=== * [[Murfreesboro, Tennessee|Murfreesboro]]: Forrest Hall at [[Middle Tennessee State University]]. The Tennessee Board of Regents has unanimously recommended the name change, on the recommendation of a campus task force, and the university president, but it has yet to pass the Tennessee Historical Commission, which plans "public hearings."<ref>{{cite web |title=MTSU Will Seek Approval to Rename Forrest Hall |first=Brian |last=Wilson |access-date=January 8, 2018 |newspaper=The Tennessean |date=April 28, 2016 |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/2016/04/28/mcphee-calls-forrest-hall-renaming/83641504/}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wkrn.com/2017/04/24/process-still-ongoing-to-change-name-of-mtsus-forrest-hall/|title=Process still ongoing to change name of MTSU's Forrest Hall|last=Flowers|first=Larry|date=April 24, 2017|website=WKRN.com|access-date=August 17, 2017}}</ref>

====Private monuments==== * [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] ** [[Nathan Bedford Forrest Statue]], made of [[fiberglass]] over foam, 25 feet high, on private land<ref name=Garrison>{{cite news |title=Forrest statue land owner fires back at blocking efforts |first=Joey |last=Garrison |date=June 23, 2015 |newspaper=The Tennessean |access-date=January 6, 2018 |url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/news/local/davidson/2015/06/23/forrest-statue-land-owner-fires-back-blocking-efforts/29161883/}}</ref> near [[Interstate 65]], installed in 1998, built with private money. It is surrounded by [[Modern display of the Confederate flag#The vernacular "Confederate flag"|Confederate battle flags]], constituting what the owner calls "Confederate Flag Park." (No government recognizes it as a park, and the entrance is chained shut with a "[[Trespassing|No Trespassing]]" sign.) The giant statue is visible from the highway to anyone entering the city from the south.<ref name=ignore /> It has been called "hideous"<ref name=ignore>{{cite news |title=A Monument the Old South Would Like to Ignore |first=Margaret |last=Renkl |date=January 29, 2018 |access-date=January 29, 2018 |newspaper=New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/29/opinion/south-monuments-nashville.html}}</ref> and "ridiculous."<ref>{{cite news |title=Kershaw's Death in ''The Times'' |first=Bruce |last=Barry |date=September 27, 2010 |access-date=January 29, 2018 |newspaper=[[Nashville Scene]] |url=https://www.nashvillescene.com/news/pith-in-the-wind/article/13035656/kershaws-death-in-the-times}}</ref> There have been numerous calls for its removal. Tennessee Governor [[Bill Haslam]] said: "It's not a statue that I like and [ [[sic]] ] that most Tennesseans are proud of in any way."<ref name=block /> Former Nashville Mayor [[Megan Barry]] called the statue "an offensive display of hatred."<ref name=block /> In 2015, Nashville's Metro Council voted to petition the [[Tennessee Department of Transportation]] to plant obscuring vegetation;<ref name="washposttheterrifyingconfederatestatue">{{cite news|last1=Holley|first1=Peter|title=The 'terrifying' Confederate statue some Tennesseans want to hide|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2015/06/25/is-this-the-weirdest-confederate-statue-in-dixie/|accessdate=September 2, 2017|work=The Washington Post|date=June 25, 2015}}</ref> the Department declined, because it is private land.<ref name=ignore /> ("Never mind that the T.D.O.T. itself removed the obscuring vegetation back in 1998, when the statue was first erected."<ref name=ignore /><ref name=block>{{cite news |title=Metro Council asks state to block view of I-65 Forrest statue |first=Joey |last=Garrison |newspaper=[[The Tennessean]] |date=July 7, 2015 |access-date=January 8, 2018 |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/insession/2015/07/08/metro-council-asks-state-to-block-view-of-i-65-forrest-statue/29848961/}}</ref>) There has been occasional vandalism; in December 2017 it was covered in "pussy-hat pink" paint,<ref name=ignore /> which Bill Dorris, current owner of the land, says he intends to leave.<ref>{{cite news |title=Vandals cover Nathan Bedford Forrest statue with pink paint |author=WKRN web staff |newspaper=[[WKRN]] |date=December 27, 2017 |access-date=January 8, 2018 |url=http://wkrn.com/2017/12/27/vandals-cover-nathan-bedford-forrest-statue-with-pink-paint/}}</ref> He also said that if trees are planted to block the view from I-65, he "would make the statue taller."<ref name=Garrison /> It was sculpted, at no charge, by notorious racist [[Jack Kershaw]], an attorney for [[James Earl Ray|Martin Luther King's murderer]], famous for having said "Somebody needs to say a good word for [[Slavery in the United States|slavery]]."<ref>{{cite news |title=Blockage sought of I-65 Nathan Bedford Forrest statue |first=Joey |last=Garrison |date=June 22, 2015 |newspaper=The Tennessean |url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/insession/2015/06/22/blockage-sought-of-i-65-nathan-bedford-forrest-statue/29128551/ |access-date=January 5, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Jack Kershaw Is Dead at 96; Challenged Conviction in King's Death |first=Douglas |last=Martin |date=September 24, 2010 |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |access-date=January 29, 2018 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/24/us/24kershaw.html}}</ref>

Lee School]] * [[Sewanee: The University of the South]]: "Nowhere is the issue of Confederate remembrance more nettlesome than at Sewanee, whose origin[s] are entwined with the antebellum South and the Confederacy."<ref name=McWhirter /> Confederate flags are in stained glass windows of the chapel, as is the [[seal (emblem)|Seal]] of the Confederacy.<ref name=McWhirter>{{cite web |title = Colleges suffer identity crisis |first = Cameron |last = McWhirter |newspaper = Atlanta Journal-Constitution |date = February 12, 2005 |url = http://www.leonidaspolk.org/Colleges%20suffer%20identity%20crisis%20%20ajc_com.htm |access-date = December 12, 2017 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060228062721/http://www.leonidaspolk.org/Colleges%20suffer%20identity%20crisis%20%20ajc_com.htm |archivedate = February 28, 2006 |df = }}</ref> It benefited greatly at its founding by a large gift from [[John Armfield]], at one time co-owner of [[Franklin and Armfield]], the largest and most prosperous slave trading enterprise in the country. Students as late as 1871 were required to wear uniforms of "cadet gray cloth".<ref>From a poster included at [[Sewanee: The University of the South]].</ref> Confederate flags hung in the chapel from its dedication in 1909 until the mid-1990s when they were removed "reportedly to improve acoustics".<ref name="auto10">{{Cite web|url=http://www.freep.com/story/opinion/contributors/2015/06/27/confederate-flag-church/29365297/|title=Confederate flag's history is 'sick' and 'twisted'|last=Danaher|first=William|date=June 27, 2015|access-date=September 5, 2017}}</ref> There is an official portrait hanging at the University of Bishop [[Leonidas Polk]], "an ardent defender of slavery,"<ref name=McWhirter /> who was in charge of the celebration of the cornerstone laying in 1857, and said the new university will "materially aid the South to resist and repel a fanatical domination which seeks to rule over us."<ref name="Carry Me Back: The Domestic Slave Trade in American Life">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-dbFUlQvcRYCe|title=Carry Me Back: The Domestic Slave Trade in American Life|author=Steven Deyle|publisher=Oxford University Press|accessdate=June 20, 2013|year=2013|pages=205–07}}</ref> He resigned his ecclesiastical position to become a major general in the Confederate army (called "Sewanee's Fighting Bishop"), and died in battle in 1864. His official portrait at the University depicts him dressed as a bishop with his army uniform hanging nearby. However, his portrait was moved from Convocation Hall to Archives and Special Collections in 2015.<ref>{{cite news |title=Sewanee, Polk, and the Old South |date=March 22, 2016 |first=Fleming |last=Smith |access-date=January 1, 2017 |url=https://thesewaneepurple.org/2016/03/22/sewanee-polk-and-the-old-south/ |newspaper=The Sewanee Purple}}</ref> The Confederate flag was also emblazoned on the university mace that led processions marking the beginning and ending of the term from 1965 until 1997. At a special chapel service to celebrate Jefferson Davis' birthday, the [[Sewanee: The University of the South#Mace controversy|Ceremonial Mace]] was consecrated to the memory of [[Nathan Bedford Forrest]], the first Grand Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, by Bishop [[Charles C. J. Carpenter]] of Alabama – one of the clergy who opposed Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s activities in Birmingham in 1963 (see [[A Call for Unity]]), prompting King to write his "[[Letter from a Birmingham Jail]]" in response.<ref name="auto10"/> **The Vice Chancellor is the chief academic officer at the university; the chancellor is a bishop of the Episcopal church. Jefferson Davis and Robert E. Lee both turned down offers of the position.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dspace.sewanee.edu/bitstream/handle/11005/2621/sewanee2008com.pdf|title=I don't know how to format this right. ''Sewanee Magazine'', "Telling the Sewanee Story," no author, Spring 2008, pp. 8–9}}</ref> (Sewanee has a portrait of Davis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tnportraits.org/davis-jefferson-sewanee.htm|title=Jefferson Davis - Unknown - The University of the South - Sewanee, Tennessee|author=|date=|website=www.TNPortraits.org|access-date=October 6, 2017}}</ref>) The first vice chancellor was Rt. Rev. [[Charles Todd Quintard]], called "chaplain of the Confederacy". GEU|date=October 6, 1863|publisher=Charleston [S.C.] : Printed by Evans & Cogswell|access-date=October 6, 2017|via=Internet Archive}}</ref> **The university's chief donor was [[John Armfield]], at the time co-owner of [[Franklin and Armfield]], the largest slave-trading firm in the U.S. He purchased the site and gave the university an endowment of $25,000 a year. In addition to Polk, Bishop [[Stephen Elliott (bishop)|Stephen Elliott]], the first and only Presiding Bishop of the [[Protestant Episcopal Church in the Confederate States of America]], and Bishop [[James Hervey Otey]], later prominent in the Confederacy, were significant founders of the university. Generals [[Edmund Kirby Smith]], [[Josiah Gorgas]], and [[Francis A. Shoup]] were prominent in the university's postbellum revival and continuance. ** Monument to Edmund Kirby Smith, Texas Avenue. ===Theme park=== * [[Pigeon Forge, Tennessee|Pigeon Forge]]: "Rebel Railroad" was a small theme park built in 1961, its main attraction being a simulated Confederate steam train which afforded "'good Confederate citizens' the opportunity to ride a five mile train route through 'hostile' territory and to help repel a Yankee assault on the train". Rebel Railroad was purchased in 1970 by [[Art Modell]], owner of the [[Cleveland Browns]].<ref>{{cite book | last = Knight | first = Gladys L. | title = Pop Culture Places: An Encyclopedia of Places in American Popular Culture | publisher = ABC-CLIO | year = 2014 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=kheDBAAAQBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q&f=false | pages = 252| isbn = 9780313398834 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Martin | first = C. Brenden | title = Tourism in the Mountain South: A Double-edged Sword | publisher = University of Tennessee Press | year = 2007 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=jC3ag3FT0e4C&lpg=PP1&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q&f=false | pages = 158, 159| isbn = 9781572335752 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Dollywood History | publisher = Dollywood | url = https://www.dollywood.com/About-Us/Dollywood-History | accessdate = November 7, 2017}}</ref> In 2018 it is operating under the name [[Dollywood]].
==Texas== {{Also|Removal of Confederate monuments and memorials#Texas}} {{further|Texas in the American Civil War}} There are at least 178 public spaces with Confederate monuments in Texas.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.co.waller.tx.us/upload/common/docs/Veterans/memorial_book.pdf|title=Directory of Memorials, Monuments, and Statues for Veterans|last=|first=|publisher=Texas Veterans Commission|year=1985|isbn=|location=Austin|pages=}}</ref><ref name=":8" /> "Nowhere has the national re-examination of Confederate emblems been more riven with controversy than the Lone Star State."<ref name=Politico />
===State capitol=== * "The Texas Capitol itself is a Confederate monument," according to then-[[Texas General Land Office|Land Commissioner]] [[Jerry E. Patterson]].<ref name=observer >{{cite news |title=The Hidden Confederate History of the Texas Capitol: An Unofficial Guide |first1=Kelsey |last1=Jukam |first2=John |last2=Savage |first3=Alisa |last3=Semiens |date=February 17, 2015 |url=https://www.texasobserver.org/hidden-confederate-history-texas-capitol-unofficial-guide/ |newspaper=Texas Observer |access-date=January 2, 2018}}</ref> ** [[Confederate Soldiers Monument (Austin, Texas)|Confederate Soldiers Monument]] (1903) features four bronze figures representing the Confederate artillery, cavalry, infantry, and navy. A bronze statue of Jefferson Davis stands above them.<ref>{{cite news | accessdate = October 29, 2017 | title = The Hidden Confederate History of the Texas Capitol: An Unofficial Guide | url = https://www.texasobserver.org/hidden-confederate-history-texas-capitol-unofficial-guide/ | work = Texas Observer}}</ref> The inscription reads: "Died for state rights guaranteed under the constitution. The people of the South, animated by the spirit of 1776, to preserve their rights, withdrew from the federal compact in 1861. The North resorted to coercion. The South, against overwhelming numbers and resources, fought until exhausted."<ref name=":24" /> ** [[Hood's Texas Brigade]], a monument "to memorialize those [who] fought for the Confederacy".<ref name="chronicle" /> "The monument includes a depiction of a Confederate soldier, quotes by Confederate leaders, a flag of the Confederacy and the Confederate battle flag."<ref name=Johnson>{{cite news |title=State Rep. Eric Johnson Wants to Spur a Discussion of Confederate Symbols by Removing Capitol Plaque |first=Rhonda |last=Fanning |date=August 17, 2017 |accessdate=June 2, 2018 |url=http://www.texasstandard.org/stories/state-rep-eric-johnson-wants-to-spur-a-discussion-on-confederate-symbols-by-removing-capitol-plaque/ |newspaper=Texas Standard ''("a service of the [[Moody College of Communication]] at the [[University of Texas at Austin]]")}}</ref> These are the only Confederate flags currently (2017) visible in the Capitol.<ref>{{citation |url=https://www.texasobserver.org/hidden-confederate-history-texas-capitol-unofficial-guide/ |newspaper=Texas Observer |date=February 17, 2015 |access-date=November 24, 2017 |title=The Hidden Confederate History of the Texas Capitol: An Unofficial Guide |first1=Kelsey |last1=Jukam |first2=John |last2=Savage |first3=Alisa |last3=Semiens}}</ref> Representative [[Eric Johnson (Texas politician)|Eric Johnson]] has called for its removal.<ref name=Johnson /> ** [[Terry's Texas Rangers Monument]], a monument "to memorialize those [who] fought for the Confederacy"<ref name="chronicle" /> (1907). ** [[Children of the Confederacy]] Creed plaque (1959). It reads: :<blockquote>Because we desire to perpetuate, in love and honor, the heroic deeds of those who enlisted in the Confederate Services, and upheld its flag through four years of war, we, the children of the South, have united in an Organization called the “Children of the Confederacy,” in which our strength, enthusiasm and love of justice can exert its influence.
:::We, therefore pledge ourselves to preserve pure ideals; to honor the memory of our beloved Veterans; to study and teach the truths of history (one of the most important of which is, that the War Between the States was not a rebellion, nor was its underlying cause to sustain slavery). and always to act in a manner that will reflect honor upon our noble and patriotic ancestors.</blockquote> ::Speaker [[Joe Straus]] in 2017 called for its removal, citing the statement "was not a rebellion, nor was its underlying cause to sustain slavery" as "not accurate, and Texans are not well-served by incorrect information about our history," in a letter to the State Preservation Board that oversees the Capitol grounds.<ref>{{cite news | last = Flynn | first = Meagan | date = September 20, 2017 | title = Speaker Joe Straus Calls for Removal of Confederate Plaque on Capitol Grounds | url = http://www.houstonpress.com/news/speaker-joe-straus-wants-children-of-the-confederacy-plaque-removed-9806645 | work = Houston Press}}</ref>. Texas House Representative [[Eric Johnson (Texas politician)|Eric Johnson]] has joined in the call for its removal.<ref>{{cite news |title=Texas House Speaker Joe Straus Calls For Removal Of 'Inaccurate' Confederate Plaque |first=Alex |last=Samuels |newspaper=[[Texas Tribune]] |date=September 19, 2017 |accessdate=June 2, 2018 |url=http://keranews.org/post/texas-house-speaker-joe-straus-calls-removal-inaccurate-confederate-plaque}}</ref> By July, 2018, more than 40 state lawmakers had called for its removal.<ref>{{cite news |title=40 Texas lawmakers in favor of removing Confederate plaque; Abbott mum |date=July 20, 2018 |first=Johnathan |last=Silver |newspaper=[[Austin American-Statesman]] |url=https://www.mystatesman.com/news/state--regional-govt--politics/texas-lawmakers-favor-removing-confederate-plaque-abbott-mum/FGBg5O2kZGbPJqfzc5vQNL/amp.html}}</ref>
===State symbols=== [[File:Reverse of the Seal of Texas.svg|thumb|right|[[Seal of Texas]]]] * The reverse side of the [[Seal of Texas]] (1992) includes "the unfurled flags of the Kingdom of France, the Kingdom of Spain, the United Mexican States, the Republic of Texas, the Confederate States of America, and the United States of America". The Confederate flag is rendered as the [[Flags of the Confederate States of America#First national flag: "The Stars and Bars|Stars and Bars]].
===State holiday=== * [[Confederate Memorial Day|Confederate Heroes Day]] is celebrated on January 19. State employees have the day off.
===Buildings=== * Austin ** The [[John H. Reagan]] state office building is located at 1400 Congress.<ref name="chronicle">{{cite news |url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/news/2017-08-18/a-guide-to-confederate-monuments-in-austin/ |newspaper=Austin Chronicle |date=August 18, 2017 |access-date=November 24, 2017 |title=A Guide to Confederate Monuments in Austin}}</ref>
===Monuments=== Many monuments were donated by pro-Confederacy groups like [[Daughters of the Confederacy]]. Once the nature of the historical context has been determined, approval of the [[Texas Historical Commission]] will be required.<ref>{{cite news |title=Judge does not expect Confederate Monument context to be added until 2019 |date=May 30, 2018 |first=Devin |last=Rarden |newspaper=[[North Texas Daily]] |url=https://www.ntdaily.com/judge-does-not-expect-confederate-monument-context-to-be-added-until-2019/}}</ref> As of September, 2018, "the county still does not have a timeline for completing the project and...there were no updates to report".<ref name=Laferney>{{cite news |title=Removal of Denton County's Confederate statue a priority for national group |first=Dalton |last=LaFerney |url=https://www.dentonrc.com/news/denton_county/removal-of-denton-county-s-confederate-statue-a-priority-for/article_c6bbe538-91a3-5116-a53f-cb9ebf4dead6.html |newspaper=[[Denton Record-Chronicle]] |date=September 9, 2018}}</ref> The video caught the attention of Kali Holloway, director of the [[Make It Right Project]], which is working to remove Confederate monuments. ===Museums=== {{Also|Texas Confederate Museum}} * [[Columbus, Texas|Columbus]]: [[Confederate Memorial Museum]]. Located in an unusual building, built in 1883, that formerly was the town's [[water tower]], and in the base its [[Fire Station]]. It is a [[Recorded Texas Historic Landmark]]. [[Curator|Curated]] by UDC, which purchased the building from the town in 1926, when its water system was modernized and the unneeded tower building put up for sale.<ref>{{cite web |title=Confederate Museum in a Water Tower |author="The Team at roadsideamerica.com" |url=https://www.roadsideamerica.com/story/29968 |accessdate=November 25, 2018}}</ref> According to the UDC it holds a collection of artifacts from Civil War solders of Columbus and [[Colorado County, Texas|Colorado County]]. It is a [[Recorded Texas Historic Landmark]], dedicated, according to UDC, to the veterans of all wars, although the museum holds only Confederate artifacts.<ref>{{cite web |title=Columbus: Confederate Memorial Museum |author=[[Texas Historical Commission]] |url=http://texasindependencetrail.com/plan-your-adventure/historic-sites-and-cities/sites/confederate-memorial-museum |accessdate=November 24, 2018}}</ref> * [[White Settlement, Texas|White Settlement]]: [[Texas Civil War Museum]], opened 2006. It is pro-Confederacy,<ref name=Lee>{{cite news |title=Trip to Texas Civil War Museum shows why Dallas should never send its Robert E. Lee statue there |newspaper=[[Dallas News]] |first=Robert |last=Wilonsky |date=April 24, 2018 |url=https://www.dallasnews.com/opinion/commentary/2018/04/24/trip-texas-civil-war-museum-shows-dallas-never-send-robert-e-lee-statue}}</ref> and the UDC has permanently one of the three seats on its board. Has material from the former [[Texas Confederate Museum]] in Austin, which closed in 1988.
